text: <@U0N3AJSSU> <@U0RSTB2DB> <@U0KPYF3PF> In my limited understanding.. if Sawtooth lake can work, it promises blockchains without the mining cost.  But I'm trying to understand the centralisation and attack vectors.  ie  Could a non-Intel node be created and added to  a blockchain that compromises the whole security of the blockchain, or can consensus generation be cryptographically limited to intel processors using the secure environment.     Think I need to do some more reading :simple_smile:
<@U10LVJD46>: at this point we are developing PoET for Intel processors
that being said, it may be possible to implement in other trusted execution environments like ARM TrustZone
PoET adds the hardware as a potential area that could be attacked, we are working on additional cryptographic security to avoid 'break once, run anywhere'
I guess if the attack involves building your own chip fabrication plant, then it offers a pretty good level of security anyway suitable for most blockchains!
Any idea if this is being used for R3's Corda?  I just noticed that they've published some new slides..
<https://d.ibtimes.co.uk/en/full/1508146/r3.png?w=683>
Interesting to see what they are using as the timestamping service.

Interesting set of requirements in a joint position paper from Accenture and Swift <https://www.finextra.com/newsarticle/28773/swift-sets-out-distributed-ledger-position?utm_medium=newsflash&utm_source=2016-4-20>

attachments.title: Swift sets out distributed ledger position
attachments.text: As the hype surrounding distributed ledger technology continues to build, Swift is acknowledging the inevitable and promising to evolve its platform to enable DLT-based services - but only when a series of &quot;critical factors&quot; have been addressed.
attachments.fallback: Finextra Research: Swift sets out distributed ledger position

text: <@U10LVJD46>: I’ve invited you to join <http://inteldl.slack.com|inteldl.slack.com>. The <#C0J02NU1E> channel is a good place to discuss Sawtooth Lake.

I added some comments to the template. For privacy requirements, we should divide them to  two sets - 1) requirements for "Permissioned" blockchain, 2) requirements for "Permissionless" blockchain.  Otherwise we will have a lot of requirements contradict each other and confuse development teams <!channel>

<@U0UL07VSL>: how strongly do you feel about this bifurcation of models?  Where do you place federated networks in this grouping, and more broadly, what about Layer 2 systems (such as Lightning or sidechains)?
<@U0RSTB2DB>:  may i also have an invite to <http://inteldl.slack.com|inteldl.slack.com> ?
I too would appreciate an invite if I may
<@U0KM61BCP>:  thanks for link, i'll read it now, i'm going to post the PDF in here so slack has a copy too
<@U0VJM7950|jonathan.mohan> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/jonathan.mohan/F12CLDCRG/swift_dlts_position_paper_final1804.pdf|swift_dlts_position_paper_final1804.pdf>

<@U0UL07VSL> <@U0KLX3284>   I think this is a good point,  probably cuts to the heart of the matter.   It seems like a dichotomy between permissioned and permissionless ledgers, but you can build a permissioned ledger on top of a permissionless blockchain (ie Ethereum / rootstock).  But not the other way round.

Its really a question for the financial regulators to answer.  Will they allow timestamping and blockchain security provided by a permissionless ledger?   I guess is that they won't have an answer for that until they see PoC's in action.

<!channel>:  Please sign up to take one of the existing use cases or a new one, modify it slightly to fit the new template, and continue to develop it. Feel free to “claim” it by editing the use case and putting your name at the top. But if you claim it, please work on it. 

The use cases are here:  <https://github.com/hyperledger/hyperledger/wiki/Use-Cases>  
The template is here: <https://github.com/hyperledger/hyperledger/wiki/Use-Case-Template>

attachments.title: hyperledger/hyperledger
attachments.text: Hyperledger Project is a new Collaborative Project at The Linux Foundation. The technical community is just getting started and will be adding code to the repository in the coming weeks. Check hype...

text: <@U0J5URUJU|nycnewman> has joined the channel
